awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Flexible Internet of Things (IoT) Smart Label Powered by Organic Photovoltaics
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will create a low-cost, flexible, Internet of Things (IoT) Smart Label that is self-powered in all lighted conditions. This Smart Label can be directly attached to packages, shipments, buildings, or worn as a medical device, enabling real-time data with improved accuracy. Sensing labels and asset trackers are extensively used to control inventories and monitor the freshness, quality, safety, and shelf life of perishable goods, as well as pharmaceuticals, foods, healthcare samples, and more. Existing radiofrequency identification (RFID) smart labels have no energy storage or energy harvesting capability. Current asset trackers have rechargeable batteries, with some powered by silicon-based photovoltaics which have poor indoor light performance. This project integrates organic photovoltaics (OPV) into flexible smart labels for continuous power supply under indoor and outdoor light, allowing frequent transmission of data to the cloud. OPV technology will be uniquely tuned to the common indoor light spectra to deliver light-to-electricity performance values over 20%, twice the indoor light performance of the best commercially available silicon photovoltaics. This program will combine flexible OPV with flexible hybrid electronics (FHE) to create a low-cost, flexible, thin, light-weight, and credit-card-sized IoT device with onboard sensors and radios for continuous wireless communication.


This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will develop a continuously-operating flexible IoT device for flexible IoT smart labels on packaging, asset tracking, and in retail. The current limitations to a completely flexible, OPV-powered IoT device are: (1) OPV has not been specifically tuned to the light emitting diode (LED) spectrum; (2) OPV has not been attached to FHE before; and (3) IoT-Smart-Label-integrated OPV has not existed in production before. Attaching the FHE to OPV is the most significant technical risk, so the goal of this project is to validate flexible OPV-powered IoT smart labels as a viable product, delivering three proof-of-concept prototypes. To achieve this primary goal, the objectives are divided into groups based on eight key elements: (1) develope OPV sheet for printed electronics integration, (2) demonstrate printed device circuits and antenna on the backside of OPV sheets, (3) determine ideal power management chip for conversion to flex-compatible form factor, (4) place and integrate silicon chips, (5) integrate and test the flexible batteries, (6) package/laminate the entire flex label, (7) demonstrate wireless data transfer from the flex IoT device to the cloud, and (8) develop roadmap for manufacturing scale-up in Phase II, including an estimate of scaled-up product cost.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
1.0 Intellectual merit and broader impacts

Current Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) smart labels and battery-powered asset trackers for healthcare, cold chain monitoring, structural health monitoring, package shipping, and retail have very limited energy sources which restrict cloud communication frequency and range. Existing RFID smart labels have no energy storage or energy harvesting capability. Current asset trackers have rechargeable batteries, with some powered by silicon-based photovoltaics which have poor indoor light performance. This project integrated thin-film organic photovoltaics into flexible smart labels and asset trackers for continuous power supply under indoor and outdoor light, allowing frequent transmission of data to the cloud. NanoFlex organic photovoltaics technology can be uniquely tuned to common LED light spectrums to deliver light-to-electricity performance values over 20%, twice the indoor light performance of the best commercially available silicon photovoltaics. In a first-of-its-kind program, NanoFlex combined flexible organic photovoltaics with flexible hybrid electronics to create a flexible, thin, and light-weight device with onboard sensors and radios for continuous wireless communication.

Sensing labels and asset trackers are extensively used to control inventories in frequently marketed consumer goods and retail industries. These labels monitor the freshness, quality, safety, and shelf life of perishable goods, as well as pharmaceuticals, foods, healthcare samples, and more. Sensing labels provide advanced solutions for retailers, distributors, and suppliers of products that are sensitive to temperature, pressure, and humidity. Sensing labels are used in threshold level detection for meat, dairy products, fresh fruits and vegetables, beverages, vaccines, blood samples, chemicals, etc. However, today operation of wireless sensor nodes is limited by the energy stored in replaceable or rechargeable batteries, requiring careful tradeoffs on communication range, types of radios used, and frequency of communication with the cloud. The NanoFlex organic-photovoltaic-powered flexible hybrid electronics technology will unlock perpetual recharging of integrated rechargeable batteries or supercapacitors in a compact-sized flexible and attachable label. This program created a proof-of-concept device, facilitating manufacturing scaleup and commercialization planning. The NanoFlex Smart Label has many applications within the global smart label and asset tracking market, including wearable health monitoring, industrial, environmental, agriculture monitoring, and structural health monitoring.

 

2.0 Publications and other products

The results of this program are confidential and proprietary and were not published.

 

3.0 Anticipated publication of project results

The results of this program may lead to future products incorporating the organic-photovoltaic-powered flexible hybrid electronics technology.


Last Modified: 05/15/2023
Modified by: Olga Griffith
